dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, big news out of the Supreme Court this week, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, big news out of the Supreme Court this week, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, totally. Like, the Google antitrust suit? Yeah, that's huge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, totally. Like, the Google antitrust suit? Yeah, that's huge.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Supreme Court Monday cleared the way for the antitrust suit that centers on Apples walled garden approach to the App store, which has drawn criticism from some companies that use it to deliver services to iPhone users.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly! They basically said, "Nope, Google, you can't just toss this out." It's about their whole, uh, "walled garden" approach to the App Store.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly! They basically said, Nope, Google, you can't just toss this out. It's about their whole, uh, walled garden approach to the App Store.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Apple sought to have the suit tossed out, arguing the iPhone owners lacked the legal standing to bring the suit.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, the 30% commission, that's the core of it, isn't it? Like, Spotify and Netflix have been really vocal about that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, the thirty percent commission, that's the core of it, isn't it? Like, Spotify and Netflix have been really vocal about that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Spotify and Netflix have taken issue with the 30% commission that Apple collects from an apps first-year subscriptions and a 15% share of revenue generated from long-term subscribers. That fee also is at the heart of the dispute that rose to the Supreme Court.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. And it goes back to these Android owners who first sued in 2011, saying Google's monopolizing the app market and those fees mean higher prices for consumers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. And it goes back to these Android owners who first sued in twenty eleven, saying Google's monopolizing the app market and those fees mean higher prices for consumers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Four iPhone owners filed a suit in 2011, claiming that Apple monopolizes the app aftermarketand extracts a fee that results in higher prices for millions of consumers who use their phones to buy food, arrange transportation or buy movie tickets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Which, um, Google tried to fight by saying those users lacked legal standing. They even cited this really old case about concrete masonry blocks!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, um, Google tried to fight by saying those users lacked legal standing. They even cited this really old case about concrete masonry blocks!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Apple sought to have the suit tossed out, arguing the iPhone owners lacked the legal standing to bring the suit. The tech company cited a decidedly analog precedent, the Illinois Brick case involving pricing of concrete masonry blocks, to argue that consumers can only sue the party that sets the retail price (in this case, the app developers).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I know, a concrete case for a digital problem! But Justice Kavanaugh, writing for the majority, basically shot that down. Said Google was trying to draw an 'arbitrary and unprincipled line.'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, a concrete case for a digital problem! But Justice Kavanaugh, writing for the majority, basically shot that down. Said Google was trying to draw an arbitrary and unprincipled line.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Justice Brett Kavanaugh, writing for the courts 5-4 majority, rejected Apples arguments, writing that the technology giant sought to draw an arbitrary and unprincipled line among retailers, based upon their arrangements with suppliers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, he even said it was like Google trying to gerrymander themselves out of these lawsuits. Pretty strong language.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, he even said it was like Google trying to gerrymander themselves out of these lawsuits. Pretty strong language.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Apples line-drawing does not make a lot of sense, other than as a way to gerrymander Apple out of this and similar lawsuits, Kavanaugh wrote.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It really is. So, the case will continue, which, you know, is a big deal. Google, of course, says they're confident they'll win.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really is. So, the case will continue, which, you know, is a big deal. Google, of course, says they're confident they'll win.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The case will continue through the courts. Apple issued a statement, saying its confident that it will prevail in court.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, they have to say that, don't they? I mean, they also argue that developers set their own prices, and most apps are free anyway.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, they have to say that, don't they? I mean, they also argue that developers set their own prices, and most apps are free anyway.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Developers set the price they want to charge for their app and Apple has no role in that. The vast majority of apps on the App Store are free and Apple gets nothing from them, Apple said in a statement.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: True, but still, that 30% cut on digital services, especially first-year subscriptions, is significant. And then 15% after that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True, but still, that thirty percent cut on digital services, especially first-year subscriptions, is significant. And then fifteen percent after that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Spotify and Netflix have taken issue with the 30% commission that Apple collects from an apps first-year subscriptions and a 15% share of revenue generated from long-term subscribers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And, uh, this isn't just about Google, right? Consumer advocates are saying this could have huge implications for Apple, Amazon... anyone with an app store.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And, uh, this isn't just about Google, right? Consumer advocates are saying this could have huge implications for Apple, Amazon... anyone with an app store.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That decision could have implications for Google or Amazon. For anyone who runs an app store.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. It sets a precedent. Spotify's CEO, Daniel Ek, was pretty vocal too, saying Google acts as both player and referee, stifling innovation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. It sets a precedent. Spotify's C E O, Daniel Ek, was pretty vocal too, saying Google acts as both player and referee, stifling innovation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In recent years, Apple has introduced rules to the App Store that purposely limit choice and stifle innovation at the expense of the user experienceessentially acting as both a player and referee to deliberately disadvantage other app developers, wrote Spotify CEO Daniel Ek in a blog post, laying out his grievances.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, remember Netflix stopped allowing new subs through Google Play last December. Spotify did something similar with their EU complaint.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, remember Netflix stopped allowing new subs through Google Play last December. Spotify did something similar with their E U complaint.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In December, Netflix said it would no longer allow new customers to pay for their monthly subscription fees through iTunes. That follows an earlier move by Spotify, which filed a complaint in March with the European Commission alleging unfair business practices.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's clear some big players are revolting. But, uh, Google Play still rakes in billions. Sensor Tower estimates $3.7 billion in a quarter.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's clear some big players are revolting. But, uh, Google Play still rakes in billions. Sensor Tower estimates three point seven billion dollars in a quarter.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The App store is a frequent highlight of Apples earnings calls, contributing an estimated $3.7 billion of the record $11.5 billion in services revenue the company reported during its most recent quarter, according to market researcher Sensor Tower.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's a lot of money. But it's also true that developers have made, like, $120 billion over the last 11 years. It's a double-edged sword, I guess.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's a lot of money. But it's also true that developers have made, like, one hundred twenty billion dollars over the last eleven years. It's a double-edged sword, I guess.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Apples app store has been a significant source of revenue for developers, who received about $120 billion over the last 11 years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. So, this is definitely one to watch. The 'walled garden' might be getting a little bit of a crack, or at least a big legal challenge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. So, this is definitely one to watch. The walled garden might be getting a little bit of a crack, or at least a big legal challenge.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Absolutely. And it'll be fascinating to see how it shapes the future of digital retail, like you said, not just for Google.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. And it'll be fascinating to see how it shapes the future of digital retail, like you said, not just for Google.
